df.deaths.plot.bar(title="Top 10 countries by deaths number", align='center', legend="deaths")

source.7efb8ea3:
from scipy.stats import pearsonr
corr, _ = pearsonr(merged_data["beds"], merged_data["deaths"])
source.b868c8e7:
from scipy.stats import spearmanr

corr, _ = spearmanr(merged_data["beds"], merged_data["deaths"])
source.f2830ff2: This chart shows us countries that have a lot of beds in hospitals for ill people. Sadly, Italy is not here which resulted in high mortality.
source.673be527: The same tendency here. Data is imbalanced.
source.0ec5db6c: ### Joint line which represents the relationship between two vars
source.2e6e7b85: It is clear that beds num and deaths are dependent but not linearly (loot at the plot). Now let's conduct some correlation analysis.
source.ee3b6228:
A Pearson correlation is a number between -1 and 1 that indicates the extent to which two variables are linearly related. 
#### In our case, beds and deaths are not linearly dependet which we already could see in plot above.
source.fcbb1196: Observable column has 50% missinng values out of all data which is bad
source.f8a5d1ec: ## Correlation Analysis between Beds num in a hospital and deaths
source.1e8cec55: Given column is not normally distributed and has a lot of outliers (imbalanced data).
source.6532f67c:
The Spearman's rank-order correlation is the nonparametric version of the Pearson product-moment correlation. Spearman's correlation coefficient, (ρ, also signified by rs) measures the strength and direction of association between two ranked variables.

#### There are definately dependent (0.7 is not long way from one). A correlation of 0.4 may not be strong enough to make a decision about relationship between two factors.
